AI.tldr: This paper proposes a new framework for fair compensation and attribution in AI-generated music by introducing direct and verifiable attribution systems.
AI.motivation: There is a growing concern that AI-generated music dilutes royalty pools and reveals flaws in current artist compensation frameworks, highlighting the inadequacies of existing solutions like licensing agreements and data attribution mechanisms.
AI.method: The research distinguishes between training and inference datasets and proposes two types of attribution—training-time and inference-time—with a focus on inference-time attribution to ensure direct, verifiable compensation. It also incorporates user control over song conditioning and transparent attribution mechanisms.
AI.result: The framework provides an equitable structure for compensating artists and rights holders whenever their music is used in conditioning generative outputs, while also making the attribution process transparent to users.
AI.conclusion: This approach offers a scalable, ethical, and practical solution to ensure fairness and provenance in AI-generated music systems, addressing a pressing issue in the music industry.

title: An Adaptive Multi Agent Bitcoin Trading System
summary:
This paper presents a Multi Agent Bitcoin Trading system that utilizes Large
Language Models (LLMs) for alpha generation and portfolio management in the
cryptocurrencies market. Unlike equities, cryptocurrencies exhibit extreme
volatility and are heavily influenced by rapidly shifting market sentiments and
regulatory announcements, making them difficult to model using static
regression models or neural networks trained solely on historical data [53].
The proposed framework overcomes this by structuring LLMs into specialised
agents for technical analysis, sentiment evaluation, decision-making, and
performance reflection. The system improves over time through a novel verbal
feedback mechanism where a Reflect agent provides daily and weekly
natural-language critiques of trading decisions. These textual evaluations are
then injected into future prompts, allowing the system to adjust indicator
priorities, sentiment weights, and allocation logic without parameter updates
or finetuning. Back-testing on Bitcoin price data from July 2024 to April 2025
shows consistent outperformance across market regimes: the Quantitative agent
delivered over 30% higher returns in bullish phases and 15% overall gains
versus buy-and-hold, while the sentiment-driven agent turned sideways markets
from a small loss into a gain of over 100%. Adding weekly feedback further
improved total performance by 31% and reduced bearish losses by 10%. The
results demonstrate that verbal feedback represents a new, scalable, and
low-cost method of tuning LLMs for financial goals.

AI.tldr: The paper develops a Multi-Agent Bitcoin Trading system leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs), achieving significant returns and losses reduction through verbal feedback mechanisms.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges of modeling the volatile cryptocurrency market, which is influenced by dynamic sentiments and data, beyond the capabilities of traditional static models.
AI.method: The trading system utilizes LLMs specifically structured into agents for tasks like technical analysis, sentiment evaluation, and decision-making. It introduces a verbal feedback mechanism for adaptive learning through natural-language critiques.
AI.result: Back-testing over a nine-month period demonstrated superior performance, achieving up to 30% higher returns in bullish markets, turning sideways market losses into 100% gains, and improving overall results by 31% with verbal feedback integration.
AI.conclusion: The study highlights verbal feedback's potential as a scalable, low-cost method for dynamically tuning LLMs to excel in financial trading and outperform traditional strategies.

title: A Novel Ensemble Learning Approach for Enhanced IoT Attack Detection: Redefining Security Paradigms in Connected Systems
summary:
The rapid expansion of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has transformed
industries and daily life by enabling widespread connectivity and data
exchange. However, this increased interconnection has introduced serious
security vulnerabilities, making IoT systems more exposed to sophisticated
cyber attacks. This study presents a novel ensemble learning architecture
designed to improve IoT attack detection. The proposed approach applies
advanced machine learning techniques, specifically the Extra Trees Classifier,
along with thorough preprocessing and hyperparameter optimization. It is
evaluated on several benchmark datasets including CICIoT2023, IoTID20,
BotNeTIoT L01, ToN IoT, N BaIoT, and BoT IoT. The results show excellent
performance, achieving high recall, accuracy, and precision with very low error
rates. These outcomes demonstrate the model efficiency and superiority compared
to existing approaches, providing an effective and scalable method for securing
IoT environments. This research establishes a solid foundation for future
progress in protecting connected devices from evolving cyber threats.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces an advanced ensemble learning-based model for IoT attack detection using machine learning techniques and demonstrates its strong performance across multiple datasets.
AI.motivation: The study aims to address the growing security vulnerabilities in IoT systems due to their increased connectivity and exposure to cyber-attacks.
AI.method: The authors propose an ensemble learning architecture involving the Extra Trees Classifier, thorough preprocessing, and optimized hyperparameters, tested on benchmark IoT security datasets.
AI.result: The proposed model achieved high recall, accuracy, precision, and minimal error rates, proving its efficiency and superiority over existing methods.
AI.conclusion: The research successfully provides a scalable and effective solution for IoT security, paving the way for future advancements in safeguarding connected devices against cyber threats.

title: Development of Mental Models in Human-AI Collaboration: A Conceptual Framework
comment:
Preprint version. Accepted for presentation at the International
  Conference on Information Systems (ICIS 2025). Please cite the published
  version when available
summary:
Artificial intelligence has become integral to organizational decision-making
and while research has explored many facets of this human-AI collaboration, the
focus has mainly been on designing the AI agent(s) and the way the
collaboration is set up - generally assuming a human decision-maker to be
"fixed". However, it has largely been neglected that decision-makers' mental
models evolve through their continuous interaction with AI systems. This paper
addresses this gap by conceptualizing how the design of human-AI collaboration
influences the development of three complementary and interdependent mental
models necessary for this collaboration. We develop an integrated
socio-technical framework that identifies the mechanisms driving the mental
model evolution: data contextualization, reasoning transparency, and
performance feedback. Our work advances human-AI collaboration literature
through three key contributions: introducing three distinct mental models
(domain, information processing, complementarity-awareness); recognizing the
dynamic nature of mental models; and establishing mechanisms that guide the
purposeful design of effective human-AI collaboration.

AI.tldr: The paper studies how human decision-makers' mental models evolve through their interaction with AI systems and proposes a socio-technical framework to guide effective human-AI collaboration.
AI.motivation: To address the gap in research regarding the evolution of human decision-makers' mental models when working with AI systems, as previous studies largely focus on the AI agent or collaboration setup.
AI.method: The authors propose a socio-technical framework identifying three mechanisms—data contextualization, reasoning transparency, and performance feedback—that influence the evolution of human mental models in human-AI collaboration.
AI.result: The paper identifies three complementary mental models necessary for human-AI collaboration: domain models, information processing models, and complementarity-awareness models. It also highlights how these models evolve dynamically.
AI.conclusion: The study advances understanding of human-AI collaboration by emphasizing the dynamic nature of mental models and offering mechanisms for designing better collaborations.

title: Detecting and Mitigating Insertion Hallucination in Video-to-Audio Generation
summary:
Video-to-Audio generation has made remarkable strides in automatically
synthesizing sound for video. However, existing evaluation metrics, which focus
on semantic and temporal alignment, overlook a critical failure mode: models
often generate acoustic events, particularly speech and music, that have no
corresponding visual source. We term this phenomenon Insertion Hallucination
and identify it as a systemic risk driven by dataset biases, such as the
prevalence of off-screen sounds, that remains completely undetected by current
metrics. To address this challenge, we first develop a systematic evaluation
framework that employs a majority-voting ensemble of multiple audio event
detectors. We also introduce two novel metrics to quantify the prevalence and
severity of this issue: IH@vid (the fraction of videos with hallucinations) and
IH@dur (the fraction of hallucinated duration). Building on this, we propose
Posterior Feature Correction, a novel training-free inference-time method that
mitigates IH. PFC operates in a two-pass process: it first generates an initial
audio output to detect hallucinated segments, and then regenerates the audio
after masking the corresponding video features at those timestamps. Experiments
on several mainstream V2A benchmarks first reveal that state-of-the-art models
suffer from severe IH. In contrast, our PFC method reduces both the prevalence
and duration of hallucinations by over 50\% on average, without degrading, and
in some cases even improving, conventional metrics for audio quality and
temporal synchronization. Our work is the first to formally define,
systematically measure, and effectively mitigate Insertion Hallucination,
paving the way for more reliable and faithful V2A models.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses the critical issue of 'Insertion Hallucination' in Video-to-Audio models, introduces evaluation metrics to measure this issue, and proposes a novel inference-time method called Posterior Feature Correction (PFC) to mitigate it.
AI.motivation: Current Video-to-Audio generation methods fail to detect misleading acoustic events known as 'Insertion Hallucinations,' driven by dataset biases such as off-screen sounds. This undermines the reliability of synthesized audio.
AI.method: The authors designed an ensemble-based evaluation framework, defined two metrics (IH@vid and IH@dur), and proposed an inference-time method, Posterior Feature Correction (PFC), using a two-pass approach to mask hallucinating video features.
AI.result: Experiments show state-of-the-art models suffer from severe insertion hallucination, which PFC mitigates by over 50% in both prevalence and duration while maintaining or improving audio quality and synchronization.
AI.conclusion: This work formally defines and tackles Insertion Hallucination, offering tools and methodologies that enhance the reliability of Video-to-Audio generation models.

title: Quantum Agents for Algorithmic Discovery
summary:
We introduce quantum agents trained by episodic, reward-based reinforcement
learning to autonomously rediscover several seminal quantum algorithms and
protocols. In particular, our agents learn: efficient logarithmic-depth quantum
circuits for the Quantum Fourier Transform; Grover's search algorithm; optimal
cheating strategies for strong coin flipping; and optimal winning strategies
for the CHSH and other nonlocal games. The agents achieve these results
directly through interaction, without prior access to known optimal solutions.
This demonstrates the potential of quantum intelligence as a tool for
algorithmic discovery, opening the way for the automated design of novel
quantum algorithms and protocols.

AI.tldr: The paper presents quantum agents trained via reinforcement learning that autonomously rediscover key quantum algorithms and protocols, highlighting the potential for automated quantum algorithm design.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to explore the use of quantum agents to autonomously discover quantum algorithms and strategies without prior knowledge, addressing the challenge of automated design in quantum computing.
AI.method: Quantum agents were trained using episodic, reward-based reinforcement learning to achieve efficient solutions for various quantum tasks and games.
AI.result: The agents autonomously rediscovered seminal quantum algorithms like Quantum Fourier Transform, Grover's search, and strategies for protocols such as CHSH winning strategies—all without prior access to optimal solutions.
AI.conclusion: The study underscores the potential of quantum intelligence for automated algorithmic discovery, paving the way for innovative and independent quantum design.

title: Computations and ML for surjective rational maps
comment: 15 pages, 2 figures, a couple of Python codes
summary:
The present note studies \emph{surjective rational endomorphisms} $f:
\mathbb{P}^2 \dashrightarrow \mathbb{P}^2$ with \emph{cubic} terms and the
indeterminacy locus $I_f \ne \emptyset$. We develop an experimental approach,
based on some Python programming and Machine Learning, towards the
classification of such maps; a couple of new explicit $f$ is constructed in
this way. We also prove (via pure projective geometry) that a general
non-regular cubic endomorphism $f$ of $\mathbb{P}^2$ is surjective if and only
if the set $I_f$ has cardinality at least $3$.

AI.tldr: The paper examines surjective rational endomorphisms on projective plane involving cubic terms, employing Python and Machine Learning for classification, and proves necessary conditions for surjectivity.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to classify surjective rational endomorphisms with indeterminacy loci in projective planes, leveraging computational techniques alongside mathematical proof to advance understanding.
AI.method: The authors use Python programming and Machine Learning to experimentally classify the maps, and apply projective geometry to derive surjectivity conditions.
AI.result: New explicit maps are discovered via computational approaches, and it is proven that such cubic endomorphisms are surjective only if the indeterminacy locus has at least three elements.
AI.conclusion: Both computational tools and pure geometry can successfully explore and characterize mathematical structures, demonstrating their complementary strengths.

title: Leveraging Whisper Embeddings for Audio-based Lyrics Matching
summary:
Audio-based lyrics matching can be an appealing alternative to other
content-based retrieval approaches, but existing methods often suffer from
limited reproducibility and inconsistent baselines. In this work, we introduce
WEALY, a fully reproducible pipeline that leverages Whisper decoder embeddings
for lyrics matching tasks. WEALY establishes robust and transparent baselines,
while also exploring multimodal extensions that integrate textual and acoustic
features. Through extensive experiments on standard datasets, we demonstrate
that WEALY achieves a performance comparable to state-of-the-art methods that
lack reproducibility. In addition, we provide ablation studies and analyses on
language robustness, loss functions, and embedding strategies. This work
contributes a reliable benchmark for future research, and underscores the
potential of speech technologies for music information retrieval tasks.

AI.tldr: WEALY, a new pipeline using Whisper decoder embeddings, offers reproducible and robust solutions for lyrics matching, rivaling state-of-the-art methods.
AI.motivation: To address issues of reproducibility and inconsistent baselines in audio-based lyrics matching methods.
AI.method: Developed WEALY, a fully reproducible pipeline using Whisper decoder embeddings, with multimodal integration of textual and acoustic features.
AI.result: WEALY matches state-of-the-art performance and provides valuable insights through ablation studies on language robustness, loss functions, and embedding strategies.
AI.conclusion: WEALY serves as a reliable, reproducible benchmark for advancing future research in music information retrieval using speech technologies.

title: Iterated Agent for Symbolic Regression
summary:
Symbolic regression (SR), the automated discovery of mathematical expressions
from data, is a cornerstone of scientific inquiry. However, it is often
hindered by the combinatorial explosion of the search space and a tendency to
overfit. Popular methods, rooted in genetic programming, explore this space
syntactically, often yielding overly complex, uninterpretable models. This
paper introduces IdeaSearchFitter, a framework that employs Large Language
Models (LLMs) as semantic operators within an evolutionary search. By
generating candidate expressions guided by natural-language rationales, our
method biases discovery towards models that are not only accurate but also
conceptually coherent and interpretable. We demonstrate IdeaSearchFitter's
efficacy across diverse challenges: it achieves competitive, noise-robust
performance on the Feynman Symbolic Regression Database (FSReD), outperforming
several strong baselines; discovers mechanistically aligned models with good
accuracy-complexity trade-offs on real-world data; and derives compact,
physically-motivated parametrizations for Parton Distribution Functions in a
frontier high-energy physics application. IdeaSearchFitter is a specialized
module within our broader iterated agent framework, IdeaSearch, which is
publicly available at https://www.ideasearch.cn/.

AI.tldr: IdeaSearchFitter utilizes Large Language Models (LLMs) within symbolic regression for accurate, interpretable solutions, outperforming several standard methods.
AI.motivation: Symbolic regression (SR), despite its scientific importance, struggles with large search spaces and model overfitting, making interpretability a challenge.
AI.method: IdeaSearchFitter uses LLMs as semantic operators within evolutionary algorithms, generating expressions informed by natural-language rationales for improved coherence and accuracy.
AI.result: The framework shows strong performance on benchmarks like FSReD, handles noisy real-world data, and provides compact parametrizations in high-energy physics.
AI.conclusion: IdeaSearchFitter effectively combines semantic guidance via LLMs with symbolic regression, addressing challenges in complexity, interpretability, and application noise.

title: A Distributed Emulation Environment for In-Memory Computing Systems
comment:
6 pages, 5 figures, 2025 IEEE International Instrumentation and
  Measurement Technology Conference (I2MTC)
summary:
In-memory computing technology is used extensively in artificial intelligence
devices due to lower power consumption and fast calculation of matrix-based
functions. The development of such a device and its integration in a system
takes a significant amount of time and requires the use of a real-time
emulation environment, where various system aspects are analyzed, microcode is
tested, and applications are deployed, even before the real chip is available.
In this work, we present the architecture, the software development tools, and
experimental results of a distributed and expandable emulation system for rapid
prototyping of integrated circuits based on in-memory computing technologies.
Presented experimental results demonstrate the usefulness of the proposed
emulator.

AI.tldr: The paper discusses a distributed emulation system for prototyping in-memory computing devices, enabling testing and deployment prior to hardware availability.
AI.motivation: The need for a real-time emulation environment to reduce development time and allow testing of in-memory computing devices before fabrication.
AI.method: Development of a distributed and expandable emulation system, along with architectural design and software tools.
AI.result: Experimental results showcased the effectiveness of the proposed emulation system in prototyping integrated circuits based on in-memory computing technologies.
AI.conclusion: The emulator aids rapid prototyping, testing microcode, and deploying applications for in-memory computing devices, illustrating its utility even before the physical chip is available.

title: New Machine Learning Approaches for Intrusion Detection in ADS-B
comment:
This is the author's version of the work accepted for publication
  Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC) 2025. The final version will be
  available via IEEE Xplore
summary:
With the growing reliance on the vulnerable Automatic Dependent
Surveillance-Broadcast (ADS-B) protocol in air traffic management (ATM),
ensuring security is critical. This study investigates emerging machine
learning models and training strategies to improve AI-based intrusion detection
systems (IDS) for ADS-B. Focusing on ground-based ATM systems, we evaluate two
deep learning IDS implementations: one using a transformer encoder and the
other an extended Long Short-Term Memory (xLSTM) network, marking the first
xLSTM-based IDS for ADS-B. A transfer learning strategy was employed, involving
pre-training on benign ADS-B messages and fine-tuning with labeled data
containing instances of tampered messages. Results show this approach
outperforms existing methods, particularly in identifying subtle attacks that
progressively undermine situational awareness. The xLSTM-based IDS achieves an
F1-score of 98.9%, surpassing the transformer-based model at 94.3%. Tests on
unseen attacks validated the generalization ability of the xLSTM model.
Inference latency analysis shows that the 7.26-second delay introduced by the
xLSTM-based IDS fits within the Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR) refresh
interval (5-12 s), although it may be restrictive for time-critical operations.
While the transformer-based IDS achieves a 2.1-second latency, it does so at
the cost of lower detection performance.

AI.tldr: The study enhances ADS-B security by developing IDS using xLSTM and transformer models, with the xLSTM model outperforming in detection accuracy and generalizability but having higher latency.
AI.motivation: The increasing reliance on the insecure ADS-B protocol in air traffic management necessitates robust intrusion detection systems (IDS) to safeguard against tampered messages and ensure situational awareness.
AI.method: The researchers created two IDS models: one based on a transformer encoder and the other using an extended Long Short-Term Memory (xLSTM). A transfer learning approach was employed, involving pre-training on benign messages and fine-tuning with tampered message datasets.
AI.result: The xLSTM-based IDS achieved an impressive F1-score of 98.9%, significantly outperforming the transformer-based model (F1-score of 94.3%). It demonstrated strong capabilities in detecting subtle and unseen attacks but introduced a higher latency of 7.26 seconds, compared to the transformer's 2.1 seconds.
AI.conclusion: xLSTM-based IDS provides heightened accuracy and generalization for ADS-B intrusion detection, proving effective even for subtle threats, though its latency may limit applicability in time-critical scenarios.

title: Navigating Sparsities in High-Dimensional Linear Contextual Bandits
summary:
High-dimensional linear contextual bandit problems remain a significant
challenge due to the curse of dimensionality. Existing methods typically
consider either the model parameters to be sparse or the eigenvalues of context
covariance matrices to be (approximately) sparse, lacking general applicability
due to the rigidity of conventional reward estimators. To overcome this
limitation, a powerful pointwise estimator is introduced in this work that
adaptively navigates both kinds of sparsity. Based on this pointwise estimator,
a novel algorithm, termed HOPE, is proposed. Theoretical analyses demonstrate
that HOPE not only achieves improved regret bounds in previously discussed
homogeneous settings (i.e., considering only one type of sparsity) but also,
for the first time, efficiently handles two new challenging heterogeneous
settings (i.e., considering a mixture of two types of sparsity), highlighting
its flexibility and generality. Experiments corroborate the superiority of HOPE
over existing methods across various scenarios.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a flexible algorithm, HOPE, that improves performance in high-dimensional linear contextual bandit problems with different types of sparsity.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of existing methods that focus on narrow types of sparsity in high-dimensional contextual bandit problems.
AI.method: A pointwise estimator was developed to handle different types of sparsity, and was incorporated into a novel algorithm called HOPE.
AI.result: HOPE demonstrated better regret bounds in homogeneous settings and successfully addressed heterogeneous settings with mixed sparsity types.
AI.conclusion: HOPE is a flexible and general solution for high-dimensional linear contextual bandits, outperforming current approaches.

title: Implementing Semantic Join Operators Efficiently
summary:
Semantic query processing engines often support semantic joins, enabling
users to match rows that satisfy conditions specified in natural language. Such
join conditions can be evaluated using large language models (LLMs) that solve
novel tasks without task-specific training.
  Currently, many semantic query processing engines implement semantic joins
via nested loops, invoking the LLM to evaluate the join condition on row pairs.
Instead, this paper proposes a novel algorithm, inspired by the block nested
loops join operator implementation in traditional database systems. The
proposed algorithm integrates batches of rows from both input tables into a
single prompt. The goal of the LLM invocation is to identify all matching row
pairs in the current input. The paper introduces formulas that can be used to
optimize the size of the row batches, taking into account constraints on the
size of the LLM context window (limiting both input and output size). An
adaptive variant of the proposed algorithm refers to cases in which the size of
the output is difficult to estimate. A formal analysis of asymptotic processing
costs, as well as empirical results, demonstrates that the proposed approach
reduces costs significantly and performs well compared to join implementations
used by recent semantic query processing engines.

AI.tldr: A novel algorithm for semantic joins using LLMs is introduced, replacing nested loop methods with a batched row approach for efficiency.
AI.motivation: Enhance efficiency in semantic query engines using LLMs for semantic joins, addressing costly processing methods.
AI.method: Batches rows from input tables into a single LLM prompt, leveraging formulas to optimize batch sizes based on LLM constraints.
AI.result: The method shows reduced processing costs and better performance compared to current approaches, supported by formal and empirical analysis.
AI.conclusion: The proposed batch-based algorithm is an effective solution for optimizing semantic join operations in LLM-powered query engines.

title: Computational and statistical lower bounds for low-rank estimation under general inhomogeneous noise
summary:
Recent work has generalized several results concerning the well-understood
spiked Wigner matrix model of a low-rank signal matrix corrupted by additive
i.i.d. Gaussian noise to the inhomogeneous case, where the noise has a variance
profile. In particular, for the special case where the variance profile has a
block structure, a series of results identified an effective spectral algorithm
for detecting and estimating the signal, identified the threshold signal
strength required for that algorithm to succeed, and proved
information-theoretic lower bounds that, for some special signal distributions,
match the above threshold. We complement these results by studying the
computational optimality of this spectral algorithm. Namely, we show that, for
a much broader range of signal distributions, whenever the spectral algorithm
cannot detect a low-rank signal, then neither can any low-degree polynomial
algorithm. This gives the first evidence for a computational hardness
conjecture of Guionnet, Ko, Krzakala, and Zdeborov\'a (2023). With similar
techniques, we also prove sharp information-theoretic lower bounds for a class
of signal distributions not treated by prior work. Unlike all of the above
results on inhomogeneous models, our results do not assume that the variance
profile has a block structure, and suggest that the same spectral algorithm
might remain optimal for quite general profiles. We include a numerical study
of this claim for an example of a smoothly-varying rather than
piecewise-constant profile. Our proofs involve analyzing the graph sums of a
matrix, which also appear in free and traffic probability, but we require new
bounds on these quantities that are tighter than existing ones for non-negative
matrices, which may be of independent interest.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates the spiked Wigner matrix problem in the context of inhomogeneous noise and computational optimality of spectral algorithms. It generalizes prior results by removing assumptions about the variance profile being block-structured and tightens existing bounds, offering numerical and theoretical insights.
AI.motivation: To explore the computational and theoretical limits of spectral algorithms for detecting low-rank signals in inhomogeneous spiked Wigner matrices and to establish whether such algorithms are optimal under broader conditions.
AI.method: The authors analyze graph sums in matrix computations, introduce sharper bounds for non-negative matrices, and compare spectral algorithms against low-degree polynomial algorithms with both theoretical proofs and numerical studies.
AI.result: The study demonstrates that the spectral algorithm remains optimal for detecting low-rank signals across a wide range of models, including cases without block-structured variance profiles. It also provides improved lower bounds for certain distributions and supports a computational hardness conjecture.
AI.conclusion: The paper strengthens the theoretical foundation for using spectral algorithms in inhomogeneous spiked Wigner models, suggesting their broad computational optimality and extending prior results to more general settings and noise profiles.

title: Where Have All the Kaczmarz Iterates Gone?
summary:
The randomized Kaczmarz (RK) algorithm is one of the most computationally and
memory-efficient iterative algorithms for solving large-scale linear systems.
However, practical applications often involve noisy and potentially
inconsistent systems. While the convergence of RK is well understood for
consistent systems, the study of RK on noisy, inconsistent linear systems is
limited. This paper investigates the asymptotic behavior of RK iterates in
expectation when solving noisy and inconsistent systems, addressing the
locations of their limit points. We explore the roles of singular vectors of
the (noisy) coefficient matrix and derive bounds on the convergence horizon,
which depend on the noise levels and system characteristics. Finally, we
provide extensive numerical experiments that validate our theoretical findings,
offering practical insights into the algorithm's performance under realistic
conditions. These results establish a deeper understanding of the RK
algorithm's limitations and robustness in noisy environments, paving the way
for optimized applications in real-world scientific and engineering problems.

AI.tldr: The paper explores the behavior of the randomized Kaczmarz (RK) algorithm for noisy and inconsistent linear systems, providing theoretical insights and validating them with experiments.
AI.motivation: Practical applications often involve noisy and inconsistent systems, yet the RK algorithm's behavior under such conditions is not fully understood.
AI.method: The paper studies the asymptotic behavior of RK iterates, analyzing the roles of singular vectors, deriving convergence horizon bounds, and conducting numerical experiments.
AI.result: It reveals the impact of noise levels and system characteristics on convergence, showing theoretical insights into RK's behavior and validating them through numerical experiments.
AI.conclusion: The findings enhance understanding of RK algorithm's limitations and robustness in noisy environments, enabling more effective use in real-world applications.
